Cartesian Product
Let $M$ be a set. The Cartesian product of $M$ with itself, denoted as $M \times M$, is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $M$.
Subgroup generated by a set

For a group $G$ and a subset $X \subset G$, the subgroup $H$ generated by $X$ is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of $G$ containing $X$. It is the unique smallest subgroup of $G$ containing $X$ and consists of all elements of the form $x_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}^{\varepsilon_{n}}$ where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ and $\varepsilon_{1}, \ldots, $\varepsilon_{n} \in \{1,-1\}$, with $n$ varying over $\mathbb{N}$.
Field
A field is a commutative division ring.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Maximal Ideal

A proper ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a maximal ideal if for any ideal $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ that contains $\mathfrak{m}$, $\mathfrak{a}$ must be either $\mathfrak{m}$ or $R$.
A-module

An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
Finitely Generated Field Extension
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called finitely generated if there exist finitely many elements $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n})$.
Prime Subfield of a Finite Field
The prime subfield of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is the smallest subfield contained within $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$, where $p=\operatorname{char} \\[\mathbb{F}\]>0$.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Disjoint Cycles
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Image of Map
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A subgroup is a subset of a group that is itself a group. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a subgroup is.
A field is a commutative division ring, so the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a field is.
An ideal is a subset of a ring that is closed under addition and multiplication by any element of the ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an ideal is.
A maximal ideal is a specific type of ideal, so the concept of an ideal must be defined to understand what a maximal ideal is.
An A-module is an abelian group with an additional structure defined by a ring A. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an A-module is.
The Galois group of a polynomial splitting field is a group of automorphisms, so the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a Galois group is.
A finitely generated field extension is a type of field extension, so the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a finitely generated field extension is.
The prime subfield of a finite field is a subfield, so the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a prime subfield is.
The Galois group of a field extension is a group of automorphisms, so the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a Galois group is.
Disjoint cycles are defined in the context of permutations, which are functions. Therefore, the concept of a function must be defined to understand what disjoint cycles are.
